>There's also a level 
difficulty rating 
> that you can specify, but I've experimented with it and it doesn't

> affect anything.

Yes, I have noticed that the difficulty level seems not to affect 
anything.  Perhaps, it was designed to par out extra points for harder 
levels?

> 
> <<Well I took both of your suggestions. First of all, I downloaded 
the 
> Tevfifty (right?) levels. Well they sure seem hard enough, however 
I'm kind 
> of disappointed with the lack of detail you put into the maps. 

If you think the tevfifty are hard, hehehe, then my scenarios must be 
impossible.  Of course, there might be an argument that my scenarios 
are impossible, but believe me when I say I playtested them with a 
100% legitimate team.  I also generally avoid freezing time when 
playtesting so I have feel for what your team might be experiencing.


>And why do 
> you choose hordes of weak lvl guys instead of some tough guys? 
(Don't take 
> it personally I'm just asking)>>

The problem with just a few tough guys is that it's really easy to go 
so high that the enemy could wipe out characters with 3 hits.  That 
would not be fun.  In fact, one of my enemies is so powerfull that he 
can open a door with 1 blow.

> 
> I thought the maps were pretty good. I strive for realism (a tall 
order in 
> this game), and what's more real than grass on the plains, trees in 
the 
> forests, water in the ocean, etc.? What else do you want? Let me 
tell you, 
> some of those levels, like the Labyrinth, were damn hard to make, 
and I'm 
> justly proud of them. And as for the enemies... if I was an overlord 
and I 
> wanted to wipe out an invading army, would I summon my soldiers and 
have 
> them attack as a unit, or would I get Jimmy Olsen's signal watch and 
summon 
> Superman to save the day? I can't think of many situations in which 
a single 
> person would be more effective in combat than an army. I take it you 
haven't 
> gotten very far yet... there are some NASTY enemy NPCs later on. 
Derrida is 
> going to kill you at least twice, I guarantee it. Unless you're 
playing on 
> Skirmish with a DPH-style cadre of demigods, that is... and where's 
the fun 
> in that?

With my illegitimate teams, I almost never play on skirmism or battle 
levels because it is no fun.  Demigods?  Heck, my best illegitimate 
teams can be wiped out on slaughter if I am not carefull.  In fact, I 
actually have fun summoning an image of a archer and using the archer 
to take out some of my own team.  I have accidently killed the 
archmage quite a few times.  This is kinda funny.  A ghost raised from 
the dead by an image of a cleric was the only thing that 'surived' 
when I accidently killed my mega archmage with an image of an archer.


As far as level numbers go, forget anything between 100 & 200.  The 
first few of 100 are used by Tyrx (as if anyone plays those scenarios) 
and the numbers left will be used by me.  Right now I am upto scenario 
136.  When all my team members reach a certain point, I will wrap up 
the saga.  The main problem is bringing my mage upto the experience 
level I want.

Speaking of mages, in a mage versus faerie battle, I find it difficult 
to keep my mage from being frozen until the scenario ends.  I tried a 
strategy of running around the faeries while using the 'warp space' 
attack and it proved pretty good, except it left my mage nearly 
drained of magic power (thankfully, I brought the intelligence level 
way up for mages).

As far as enemies go, once they reach level 12, they have all their 
available attacks (indirectly, I am saying that point makes them so 
much tougher).  Also, remember: named enemies are harder to defeat  
than unnamed enemies.  Third, take all of my comments in stride with 
what kind of team I am using.  Right now, I am just getting around to 
having 100% level 10 enemies or higher (mainly out of caution).  It 
took a lot of scenarios to build a team to the point of not having too 
much trouble with level 10s.  I will do good to end up with 100% level 
30s (except for  single enemy scenarios) on the main path.  Even then, 
it will not be against mages, achmages, and probably faeries (if I use 
them by themselves).
